clauses.clause: This directive takes effect on April 1, 2020 .

This directive replaces the following Treasury Board policy instruments:
Directive on Management of Information Technology, April 1, 2009
Directive on Information Management Roles and Responsibilities, October 8, 2007
Directive on Recordkeeping, June 1, 2009
Policy on Acceptable Network and Device Use, October 1, 2013 , Appendices A, B, C, and D.
This directive is issued pursuant to the same authority indicated in sectionÂ 2 of the Policy on Service and Digital .
The Treasury Board has delegated to the President of the Treasury Board the authority to issue, amend and rescind this directive.

The Treasury Board has delegated to the Chief Information Officer (CIO) of Canada the authority to issue, amend and rescind supporting instruments, including standards, mandatory procedures and other appendices.
The objectives indicated in sectionÂ 3 of the Policy on Service and Digital apply to this directive.
The expected results indicated in sectionÂ 3 of the Policy on Service and Digital apply to this directive.

The CIO of Canada is responsible for:
Leveraging technology
Defining requirements and criteria of AppendixÂ D: Standard on Information Technology User and Workpoint Profiles and AppendixÂ E: Standard on Information Technology Provisions .

The deputy head of Shared Services Canada (SSC) is responsible for:
Leveraging technology
Providing services within their mandate respecting the provisions, limits and thresholds specified in AppendixÂ D: Standard on Information Technology User and Workpoint Profiles and AppendixÂ E: Standard on Information Technology Provisions ;
Providing departmental CIOs and the CIO of Canada with details on service offering, availability and their departmentâs actual consumption, subject to data availability; Releasing for publication on the Open Government portal enterprise-wide annual statistics on availability and actual consumption, subject to data availability; and Providing to departments, subject to data availability, inventories of applications and associated software and versions.

The designated official for cyber security, in collaboration with the departmental CIO and Chief Security Officer as appropriate, is responsible for:
Leveraging technology
Cyber security
Ensuring that cyber security requirements and appropriate risk-based measures are applied continuously in an identify, protect, detect, respond and recover approach to protect information systems and services, in accordance with the
Directive on Security Management , AppendixÂ B: Mandatory Procedures for Information Technology Security Control
;
Ensuring that departmental plans, processes and procedures are in place for responding to cyber security events and reporting of incidents to the appropriate authorities and affected stakeholders, in accordance with the Government of Canada Cyber Security Event Management Plan ;
Undertaking immediate action within the department as directed to assess impacts, including whether there has been a privacy breach, and implement mitigation measures in response to cyber security events; and Liaising with the access to information and privacy office in the department and the Office of the Privacy Commissioner when there has been a material privacy breach.

Employees are responsible for:
Open and strategic management of information and data
Recordkeeping
Documenting their activities and decisions of business value.

Managers are responsible for:
Open and strategic management of information and data
Recordkeeping
Informing employees of their duty to document their activities and decisions of business value.
The roles of other government organizations in relation to this directive are described in sectionÂ 5 of the Policy on Service and Digital .

This directive applies to departments as defined in sectionÂ 2 of the
Financial Administration Act
unless otherwise excluded by other acts, regulations or orders in council.

RequirementsÂ 4.2.1, 4.2.2, 4.2.3, 4.2.4, 4.3.19, 4.3.20 and 4.3.21, apply only to departments, as defined in sectionÂ 2 of the
Financial Administration Act
, that receive their IT services from SSC as set out in Order-in-Council 2015-1071 . Other departments or separate agencies that are not subject to these provisions are encouraged to meet these requirements as good practice.

RequirementÂ 4.3.24 applies only to the core public administration as defined in subsectionÂ 11.1 of the
Financial Administration Act
, unless otherwise excluded by specific acts, regulations or orders-in-council. Other departments or separate agencies that are not subject to these provisions are encouraged to meet these requirements as good practice.

Agents of Parliament
The heads of the following organizations are solely responsible for monitoring and ensuring compliance with this directive within their organizations:
Office of the Auditor General
Office of the Chief Electoral Officer
Office of the Commissioner of Lobbying of Canada
Office of the Commissioner of Official Languages
Office of the Information Commissioner of Canada
Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada
Office of the Public Sector Integrity Commissioner of Canada
With regard to Agents of Parliament, the following subsections do not apply: 4.3.1, 4.3.2, 4.3.3, 4.3.4, 4.3.5, 4.3.10, 4.3.12 and 4.3.25.
The references in relation to this directive are described in sectionÂ 8 of the Policy on Service and Digital .
For interpretation of any aspect of this directive, contact Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat Public Enquiries .
